metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: automatic weather station of Dashalong station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Dashalong station from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (98.941° E, 38.840° N) was located on a swamp meadow surface in the Longshatan, which is near west of Qilian county, Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3739 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45C; 5 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (010C/020C; 10 m, north), air pressure (PTB110; in the tamper box on the ground), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), and soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m; RH_5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. Due to the malfunction of data logger, data during June to September were missing. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2022-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.
research objective: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China.
This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.

However, the above modeling efforts suffered from 1) the availability of the forcing data (only two weather stations operated by the Chinese Meteorological Administration functioned in the upper reaches of the HRB) and 2) a lack of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.

methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor snow cover properties in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: Snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments, including measuring snow depth with ultrasonic sensors and snow water equivalent with GammaMONitor devices.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key characteristics of meteorological and hydrological data collection methods in alpine regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: automatic meteorological stations, superstations, wind speed, wind direction, air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, precipitation, snow accumulation, snow ablation, soil physics datasets, freeze-thaw processes

Definition.Question: What does 'gap-free meteorological data' refer to in hydrological data collection?
Definition.Answer: Gap-free meteorological data refers to a continuous data record without missing values, which is crucial for accurate monitoring and modeling of hydrological processes. This type of data is collected through a network of automatic meteorological stations that ensure consistent and reliable measurements for hydrological research.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'freeze-thaw cycles' in alpine hydrology research?
Definition.Answer: Freeze-thaw cycles are significant in alpine hydrology research because they influence water infiltration, surface runoff, and groundwater dynamics. These cycles, along with soil moisture and snowmelt processes, are critical for understanding hydrologic and ecohydrological processes in alpine regions and are a focus of observation in networks like the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods employed in automatic meteorological stations in the Heihe River Basin compare to those utilized in the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) for capturing hydrometeorological data?
Comparison.Answer: The automatic meteorological stations in the Heihe River Basin utilize a combination of AMSs and superstations to monitor variables like wind speed, air temperature, humidity, and soil conditions, while INARCH connects individual observatories globally to form an international data-sharing network, emphasizing snow and frozen ground observations. Both aim to capture comprehensive hydrometeorological data, but INARCH's approach is more globally distributed and collaborative.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred for collecting accurate soil moisture and temperature data in high-altitude regions, considering potential technological barriers?
Interpretation.Answer: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored using an observation network that includes automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations. Soil temperature and moisture were measured in multiple layers at each AMS, and a wireless sensor network (WSN) was established to capture seasonal changes. These methods help to overcome access difficulties and technological barriers in high-altitude regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of snow cover and frozen ground observation data contribute to the improvement of alpine hydrological models?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of snow cover and frozen ground observation data can provide accurate forcing data for hydrological models, validate remote sensing data, and allow the evaluation of distributed models. Observations of snow depth, snow water equivalent, and soil temperature and moisture contribute to understanding the freeze-thaw processes and their impacts on hydrology.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges contribute to the scarcity of observation data in alpine regions, and how do they affect data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed. These challenges hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks in alpine regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research. This scarcity has motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing a multiscale observation network for hydrometeorological data collection in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing a multiscale observation network can provide comprehensive datasets that are crucial for accurately modeling hydrological processes, validating remote sensing data, and evaluating distributed models. This can enhance the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions, ultimately aiding in addressing scientific questions related to climate change and human activities.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the establishment of automatic meteorological stations impact the quality and availability of data for alpine hydrology research?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of automatic meteorological stations can significantly improve the quality and availability of data, providing gap-free meteorological and hydrological information. This facilitates better parameterization of hydrological models, validation of remote sensing products, and supports a wide range of scientific inquiries related to snow cover, frozen ground, and other hydrometeorological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of establishing an integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives of establishing an integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the Heihe River Basin include providing accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validating remote sensing data, evaluating distributed models, and improving predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. The network aims to address scientific questions related to the impact of climate change and human activities on these processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to include high-resolution soil physics datasets in the observation network for alpine hydrology research?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including high-resolution soil physics datasets is important for capturing freeze-thaw processes, which are critical for understanding water infiltration, surface runoff, and groundwater dynamics in alpine hydrology. These datasets help in evaluating the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models and provide insights into the dynamic hydrothermal processes within the soil, which are influenced by soil density, moisture content, and temperature.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in ensuring the quality control of meteorological data collected from an alpine observation network?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection process involves several quality control steps: ensuring a complete dataset with 144 entries per day (one every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that is physically improbable or out of instrument range, marking questionable data in red, and standardizing the date and time format in a single column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can an integrated observation network be structured to effectively capture snow cover and frozen ground processes in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An integrated observation network can be structured with multiple automatic meteorological stations and superstations for comprehensive data collection. These include stations for capturing meteorological variables like wind, air temperature, humidity, and radiation, as well as superstations for collecting snow depth, snow water equivalent, and soil temperature and moisture. The network should also validate remote sensing products using fine-resolution data from these superstations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methods used to address data scarcity and enhance the prediction of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methods to address data scarcity include setting up a distributed and multiscale observation network to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, integrating observations with simulations, and using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation. Additionally, validation and calibration of remote sensing data are necessary due to the complexities of the earth system, particularly in alpine regions.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the establishment of a comprehensive observation network for collecting hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network has been enabled by the use of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations. These stations employ state-of-the-art techniques and instruments, such as SR50A for snow depth measurement, GMON for snow water equivalent (SWE), and FlowCapt for blowing snow flux, allowing for detailed monitoring of hydrological processes and snow cover dynamics.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing techniques integrate with ground-based observation networks to enhance the predictive understanding of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing techniques can be integrated with ground-based observation networks by providing validation and calibration of remote sensing data. This integration helps in improving the prediction of hydrological processes by providing accurate forcing data and enabling the evaluation of distributed models, particularly in complex terrains like those found in the alpine region.

Expectation.Question: Why is it expected that remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing data, when combined with data assimilation, is expected to improve the prediction of hydrological processes due to its potential to provide comprehensive spatial coverage and continuous temporal monitoring, which can supplement the scarce in-situ observation data often encountered in alpine regions. However, complexities in the earth system and uncertainties in remote sensing data, particularly in alpine environments, necessitate validation and calibration to achieve accurate predictions.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be difficult to ensure consistent data collection from automatic meteorological stations in remote alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: Consistent data collection from automatic meteorological stations in remote alpine regions may be difficult due to logistical challenges such as access difficulties, technological barriers, and environmental factors like extreme weather conditions and variable topography. These challenges can lead to intermittent data loss, sensor malfunctions, and the need for robust instrumentation and maintenance strategies to ensure data integrity.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges faced in collecting meteorological data in alpine regions, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection in alpine regions. These challenges hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and hydrological models. Addressing them requires the establishment of integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks, as well as the use of state-of-the-art techniques and instruments for data collection, such as automatic meteorological stations and superstations for capturing snow and frozen ground data.

Judgmental.Question: How can data from meteorological observations be effectively integrated with remote sensing data to enhance predictions of hydrological processes?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of meteorological observations with remote sensing data can significantly enhance predictions of hydrological processes by providing high-quality, accurate forcing data. Using data assimilation techniques to combine the ground-based observations from automatic meteorological stations with remote sensing products allows for the validation and calibration of complex models. This integrated approach reduces uncertainties in remote sensing data and improves the predictive understanding of hydrological processes, especially in challenging environments like the alpine region.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection in remote alpine regions can be consistent given the harsh climate and complex terrain.
Assertion.Answer: Data collection in remote alpine regions is challenging due to the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography. However, an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network has been established with automatic meteorological stations and superstations to monitor gap-free meteorological and hydrological data. These networks aim to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models and validate remote sensing products, despite challenges such as access difficulties and technological barriers.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how snow cover and frozen ground data enhance the understanding of hydrological processes in alpine regions.
Assertion.Answer: Snow cover and frozen ground data are crucial for understanding hydrological processes in alpine regions because they are key drivers of water infiltration, surface runoff, and groundwater dynamics. Snow water equivalent (SWE) and freeze-thaw cycles alter the hydrological processes significantly. The data collected at snow and frozen ground superstations provide critical insights into these processes, enabling the development of more accurate hydrological models and the validation of remote sensing products. Such data help address scientific questions related to how climate change and human activities alter fundamental hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methods used to ensure the accuracy and quality control of data collected from an observation network in the alpine region.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection from the alpine region is handled by ensuring that each day comprises 144 data entries, each collected every 10 minutes, with missing data marked by -6999. Observations are scrutinized for duplicate records, and data that are clearly beyond physical meanings or instrument limits are removed. Some data elements that are questionable are highlighted in red. The format for date and time is standardized, and the naming convention for datasets follows a specific rule.
